title:
Strong Structural Bounds for MaxSAT: The Fine Details of Using
  Neuromorphic and Quantum Hardware Accelerators

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Hardware accelerators like quantum annealers or neuromorphic chips are capable of finding the ground state of a Hamiltonian. A promising route in utilizing these devices is via methods from automated reasoning: The problem at hand is first encoded into MAXSAT; then MAXSAT is reduced to MAX2SAT; and finally, MAX2SAT is translated into a Hamiltonian. It was observed that different encodings can dramatically affect the efficiency of the hardware accelerators. Yet, previous studies were only concerned with the size of the encodings rather than with syntactic or structural properties.

We establish structure-aware reductions between maxsat, max2sat, and the quadratic unconstrained binary optimization problem (QUBO) that underlies such hardware accelerators. All these problems turn out to be equivalent under linear-time, treewidth-preserving reductions. As a consequence, we obtain tight lower bounds under ETH and SETH for MAX2SAT and QUBO, as well as a new time-optimal fixed-parameter algorithm for QUBO. While our results are tight up to a constant additive factor for the primal treewidth, we require a constant multiplicative factor for the incidence treewidth. To close the emerging gap, we supplement our results with novel time-optimal algorithms for fragments of MAXSAT based on model counting.

## 1 Introduction

The maximum satisfiability problem (MAXSAT) is the canonical task of cost-optimal reasoning. Given is a weighted propositional formula in conjunctive normal form (WCNF) like

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varphi= & \left(x_{1} \vee x_{2} \vee x_{3}\right)^{2} \wedge\left(\neg x_{1} \vee x_{2}\right)^{\infty} \wedge\left(x_{1} \vee \neg x_{2}\right)^{\infty} \\
& \wedge\left(\neg x_{1} \vee \neg x_{2}\right)^{5} \wedge\left(x_{1} \vee x_{2} \vee \neg x_{3}\right)^{120} \wedge\left(x_{3}\right)^{100}
\end{aligned}
$$

The goal is to find the model that minimizes the weights of the falsified clauses. (Here and in the rest of the article, the exponents indicate the weights of the clauses.) It is well-known in the theoretical computer science literature that maxsat remains NP-hard if every clause contains at most two literals, i.e., MAX2SAT is NP-hard [20]. This is in stark contrast to the satisfiability problem, which is well known to be solvable in polynomial time on such formulas [25]. The hardness result of MAX2SAT imposes an encoding from MAXSAT into MAX2SAT, which, however, is so far deemed as of purely theoretical interest. While there are well-established MAXSAT solvers [31, 22, 40] and specialized solvers for fragments like Horn formulas [30], we are not aware of any tool that actively utilizes binary clauses.

The relevance of reductions from MAXSAT to MAX2SAT has increased during the last few years due to rapid developments in specialized hardware accelerators that are able to find the ground state of an Ising model. These chips, called Ising machines, Ising processing units, or IPUs [16], obtain as input a Hamiltonian

$$
H\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} x_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=i+1}^{n} w_{i j} x_{i} x_{j}
$$

with binary variables $x_{i} \in\{0,1\}$ (also called spins) and weights $w_{i j} \in \mathbb{Z} .{ }^{1}$ The ground state of the Ising model is the vector $\vec{x} \in\{0,1\}^{n}$ that minimizes $H(\vec{x})$. An IPU is an abstraction of a chip that obtains as input just the weights $w_{i j}$ (say in the form of an $n \times n$ upper triangular matrix) and that outputs the ground state of the system, ${ }^{2}$ see Figure 1.

Figure 1: Illustration of an IPU that operates on an $n$-variable Ising model $H\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$. The input are the weights of $H$ given as $n \times n$ upper triangular matrix ( $n$ is fixed). The output is a vector $\vec{x} \in\{0,1\}^{n}$ that minimizes $H(\vec{x})$.

$$
H\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \text { as } W \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}
$$

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

$$
x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in\{0,1\}^{n} \text { minimizing } H\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)
$$

The Ising model approach gained momentum since it naturally appeared in various promising technologies simultaneously. Perhaps the best-known IPU is the quantum annealer by D-Wave [23], which claims to utilize quantum effects to find the ground state. The usability of quantum-based IPUs is, for instance, actively explored in satellite scheduling [21, 2] and for efficient coalition formations among LEO satellites [46]. Another area in which Ising machines naturally appear are neuromorphic chips [3] such as Intel's Loihi [19] or IBM's TrueNorth system [1]. This hardware implements physical artificial neurons to perform computations, often in mixed analog-digital implementations. It promises low-energy computations [43] in radiation-resistant hardware [36], making it a promising technology for future space applications $[4,39]$. The rising interest in Ising machines also led companies like Fujitsu Limited [32] or Toshiba [24] to develop ipus based on classical hardware.

The problem underlying the IPU (find the minimum of $H=\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} x_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=i+1}^{n} x_{i} x_{j} w_{i j}$ ) is called quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO). Utilizing an IPU, thus, requires to encode problems into QUBOs $[14,15]$. A common route in doing so is to use well-established encodings into maxsat and to then encode maxsat into qubo [8, 13, 35, 48, 38]. While it was experimentally observed that the choice of the encoding can significantly impact the performance of the Ising machine [26, 49], surprisingly, no study has been performed so far that takes properties of the encoding into account other than its pure size. In particular, to our knowledge, there is no study that takes syntactic and structural properties of the given maxsat instance into account - even though it is known that treewidth-based approaches are competitive for MAXSAT [7] and that IPUs may only be usable with Hamiltonians that have small treewidth [47].

# 1.1 Contribution I: Treewidth-aware Reductions between MaxSAT and QUBO 

Our main results are fine-grained reductions between maxsat variants and qubo. In fact, we prove that these problems are equivalent under linear-time reductions that preserve the primal or incidence treewidth. The primal treewidht $\operatorname{tw}(\varphi)$ is the treewidth of the graph $G_{\varphi}$ that contains a vertex for every variable and that connects variables that appear together in a clause; the incidence treewidth $\operatorname{itw}(\varphi)$ is the treewidth of the variable-clause interaction graph $I_{\varphi}$ that contains a vertex for every variable and every clause and that connects variables to clauses that contain them - formal definitions are given in Section 2.1. Figure 2 provides a more detailed overview of Theorem 1.

Theorem 1 (Main Theorem). Given a wcnf and a corresponding tree decomposition, the following reductions hold:

1. MAXSAT $\equiv \frac{\ln }{1 \mathrm{~T}}+2 \mathrm{MAX} 2 \mathrm{SAT} \equiv \frac{\ln }{3 \mathrm{~T}}+2 \mathrm{QUBO}$
2. MAXSAT $\equiv \frac{\ln }{3 \mathrm{itw}} \operatorname{MAX} 2 \mathrm{SAT} \equiv \frac{\ln }{3 \mathrm{itw}} \mathrm{QUBO}$

For Item 1, a tree decomposition is not required as input.
Corollary 1 (QUBO Upper Bound). The ground state of a QUBO $H$ can be computed in $O\left(2^{\operatorname{tw}(H)}|H|\right)$.
Corollary 2 (MAX2SAT Lower Bound). Unless SETH fails, solving MAX2SAT requires a running time of $\Omega\left(2^{\operatorname{tw}(\varphi)}\right) \cdot \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)$ or $\Omega\left(2^{\operatorname{itw}(\varphi) / 3}\right) \cdot \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)$.

Assuming ETH, MAX2SAT cannot be solved in $2^{o(\operatorname{tw}(\varphi))} \cdot \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)$ or $2^{o(\operatorname{itw}(\varphi))} \cdot \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ The physics literature often uses weights in $\mathbb{R}$, but any fixed-precision approximation of $\mathbb{R}$ can be represented in $\mathbb{Z}$.
    ${ }^{2}$ Many realizations of ipus, such as the D-Wave quantum annealer, output only a heuristic solution. In our theoretical model, however, we assume the IPU to be an exact solver.

Figure 2: An overview of our reductions between various variants of maxsat. All reductions in the picture are linear-time computable. An arrow $A^{\mathrm{a} \mathrm{tw}, x b} B$ means that if the instance of $A$ has primal treewidth tw, the instance of $B$ has primal treewidth at most $a \mathrm{tw}+b$. If the label of an arrow is " $\max (\mathrm{tw}, x)$ ", the reduction increases the treewidth to at most $x$. Finally, if the arrow is dashed, the reduction requires a tree decomposition as input. The green arrows are implied by the transitive closure.
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Corollary 3 (QUbo Lower Bound). Unless SETH fails, qubo requires a running time of $\Omega\left(2^{\mathrm{tw}(H)}\right)$. $\operatorname{poly}(|H|)$ or $\Omega\left(2^{\mathrm{itw}(H) / 3}\right) \cdot \operatorname{poly}(|H|)$.

Assuming ETH, QUBO cannot be solved in $2^{o(\operatorname{tw}(H))} \cdot \operatorname{poly}(|H|)$ or $2^{o(\operatorname{itw}(H))} \cdot \operatorname{poly}(|H|)$.

We refer the reader unfamiliar with the (strong) exponential time hypothesis (SETH and ETH) to the survey by Lokshtanov et al. [28]. Intuitively, in the context of structural parameters, ETH implies that 3sat cannot be solved in $2^{o(\operatorname{tw}(\varphi))}$ poly $(|\varphi|)$ while SETH implies SAT cannot be solved in $o\left(2^{\operatorname{tw}(\varphi)}\right)$ poly $(|\varphi|)$.

# 1.2 Contribution II: New Algorithms for Variants of MaxSAT 

The reductions in Figure 2 imply new lower bounds for qubo and max2sat that match the corresponding upper bounds for the primal treewidth. For the incidence treewidth, the implied lower bounds have the form $\Omega\left(2^{\text {itw }(\varphi) / 3} \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)\right)$ while the implied upper bounds have the form $O\left(2^{2 \operatorname{itw}(\varphi)} \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)\right)$ (via the folklore dynamic program). We narrow this gap by improving the upper bound:

Theorem 2. MAX2SAT and QUBO can be solved in time $O\left(2^{\text {itw }(\varphi)}|\varphi|\right)$.
The central part of the proof of the theorem uses the fact that clauses and terms in both problems are binary. We supplement these findings with new upper bounds for fragments of maxsat that have unbounded clause sizes. The idea is to establish treewidth-aware reductions from these problems to \#SAT, the problem of counting the number of satisfying assignments of an (unweighted) propositional formula.

## Theorem 3.

1. UNARY-MAXSAT $\leq_{\text {itw }+1}^{\text {lin }} \#$ SAT
2. MULT-MAXSAT $\leq_{\text {itw }+1}^{\text {lin }} \#$ SAT
3. LEX-MAXSAT $\leq_{\text {itw }+1}^{\text {lin }} \#$ SAT

Corollary 4. UNARY-MAXSAT, MULT-MAXSAT, and LEX-MAXSAT can be solved in time $O\left(2^{\text {itw }(\varphi)}|\varphi|\right)$.
Proof. Use Theorem 3 and an algorithm with this running time for \#SAT [44].

### 1.3 Related Work

A reduction from SAT to MAX2SAT is known since 1976 [20]. This reduction was improved by Trevisan et al. [45] and is still a field of research. An overview of recent developments is given by Ansotegui et al. [5]. Connections between maxsat and it's multiplicative and lexicographic version, i.e., mult-Maxsat and LEX-MAXSAT, are well known [29].

Reducing maxsat to its binary version turned out to be a central part of embeddings into adiabatic quantum computers, quantum annealers [6, 8, 13, 18, 41, 42], and systems that emulate artificial intelligence in hardware such as neuromorphic chips [3, 33]. Consequently, optimal (with respect to some property) reductions from maxsat to max2sat and qubo are actively researched [35]. Current trends include algorithmic formulations [37] and data-driven automatic generation of Qubos [34]. However, to the best of our knowledge, no work considered structural properties of these reductions so far.

# 1.4 Structure of this Article 

The following section provides the necessary background in propositional logic and structural graph theory. The subsequent section proves the main theorem as a series of reduction rules. Each of these rules obtains as input a formula of some fragment of MAXSAT and modifies it slightly. The proof of Theorem 1 boils down to showing that applying these rules exhaustively results in a MAX2SAT or QUBO instance, and that these rules can be applied exhaustively in linear time without increasing the input's treewidth. We extend this result with new upper bounds for fragments of MAXSAT using tools from probabilistic reasoning and conclude in the last section.

## 2 Preliminaries

A literal $\ell$ is variable $x$ or its negation $\neg x$. We refer to the variable of a literal with $|\ell|$. A clause is a set of literals, and a propositional formula in conjunctive normal form (a CNF) is a set of clauses. A weighted CNF (a WCNF) is a CNF $\varphi$ together with a weight function $w: \varphi \rightarrow \mathbb{N} \cup\{\infty\}$. Clauses with finite weight are called soft, and the others hard. We denote formulas in the usual logical notation and use the superscript of clauses to denote their weight. For instance, the formula from the introduction refers to

$$
\varphi \equiv\left\{\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}\right\},\left\{\neg x_{1}, x_{2}\right\},\left\{x_{1}, \neg x_{2}\right\},\left\{\neg x_{1}, \neg x_{2}\right\},\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, \neg x_{3}\right\},\left\{x_{3}\right\}\right\}
$$

with, e.g., $w\left(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}\right\}\right)=2$. We denote the variables in $\varphi$ with $\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)$. An assignment $\beta$ of $\varphi$ is a set of literals with $\{|\ell| \mid \ell \in \beta\}=\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)$ and $|\beta|=|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|$. An assignment $\beta$ satisfies a clause $c$ if $\beta \cap c \neq \emptyset$, which we denote by $\beta \models c$. The cost of an assignment is the sum of the falsified clauses: $\operatorname{cost}(\beta)=\sum_{c \in \varphi, \beta \mid \forall c} w(c)$. The cost of a formula $\varphi$ is the minimum cost any assignment $\beta$ of $\varphi$ must have, i.e., $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi)=\min _{\beta} \operatorname{cost}(\beta)$. An assignment satisfies a formula $(\beta \models \varphi)$ if it has a finite cost.

Example 1. For the previous formula we have $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi) \leq 5$ witnessed by $\operatorname{cost}\left(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{5}\right\}\right)=5$ (only $\left(\neg x_{1} \vee \neg x_{2}\right)$ is falsified). It is easy to check that indeed $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi)=5$.

We define the monotone version of MAXSAT as the problem in which all variables occur negated. Since this problem is trivial if all clauses have a non-negative weight, we allow $w: \varphi \rightarrow \mathbb{Z} \cup\{\infty\}$ for monotone formulas.

### 2.1 Structural Graph Theory for Propositional Logic.

A graph $G$ consists of a set of vertices $V(G)$ and a set $E(G)$ of two-element subsets of $V(G)$ called edges. The primal graph $G_{\varphi}$ of a WCNF $\varphi$ is the graph with $V\left(G_{\varphi}\right)=\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)$ that connects two vertices if the corresponding variables appear together in a clause. The incidence graph $I_{\varphi}$ is the bipartite graph with $V\left(I_{\varphi}\right)=\varphi \cup \operatorname{vars}(\varphi)$ that connects variables to the clauses containing them.

A tree decomposition of a graph $G$ is a (rooted) directed tree $T$ with a mapping $\chi: V(T) \rightarrow 2^{V(G)}$ such that:

Connectedness For every $v \in V(G)$ the induced subgraph $T[\{t \in V(T) \mid v \in \chi(t)\}]$ is a nonempty directed tree.

Covering For every $\{u, v\} \in E(G)$ there is a $t \in V(T)$ with $\{u, v\} \subseteq \chi(t)$.
The width of $(T, \chi)$ is $\max _{t \in V(T)}|\chi(t)|-1$, and the treewidth $\operatorname{tw}(G)$ of $G$ is the minimum width of any tree decomposition of $G$. The primal and incidence treewidth of a formula $\varphi$ is the treewidth of $G_{\varphi}$ and $I_{\varphi}$, respectively:

$$
\operatorname{tw}(\varphi):=\operatorname{tw}\left(G_{\varphi}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{itw}(\varphi):=\operatorname{tw}\left(I_{\varphi}\right)
$$

We do not enforce any further requirements on tree decompositions, but note that since $T$ is rooted, there is a unique $\operatorname{root}(T)$ and every node $t \in V(T)$ has a set children $(t)$. For a vertex $v \in V(G)$ we denote with $\operatorname{root}(T, v)$ the root of the subtree $T[\{t \in V(T) \mid v \in \chi(t)\}]$.

Example 2. The treewidth of the Centaurus constellation (as graph shown on the left) is at most two, as proven by the tree decomposition on the right:

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

All these definitions extend to quadratic binary optimization problems QUBOs in a natural way: Just interpret a Hamiltonian $H=\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} x_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=i+1}^{n} x_{i} x_{j} w_{i j}$ as a set of sets, where each of the inner sets corresponds to a term.

# 3 From MaxSAT to QUBO and Back 

All statements in this section are proven with a series of reduction rules. Each rule obtains as input a WCNF $\varphi$ and is either applicable, in which case a new $\varphi^{\prime}$ is output, or not, in which case nothing happens. When applying a rule $i$, we always assume that all rules $j<i$ are not applicable. In any reduction rule, $\alpha$ will refer to a fresh auxiliary variable produced by the application of the rule. To illustrate this idea, the following two rules transform any WCNF into the standard form in which all soft clauses are non-trivial and unit.

Rule 1. Applicable if there is a $c=\left(\ell_{1} \vee \cdots \vee \ell_{q}\right)^{w}$ with $w=0$.
Delete $c$.
Rule 2. Applicable for $c=\left(\ell_{1} \vee \cdots \vee \ell_{q}\right)^{w}$ with $w<\infty$ and $q>1$.
Replace $c$ with $(\alpha)^{w} \wedge\left(\ell_{1} \vee \cdots \vee \ell_{q} \vee \neg \alpha\right)^{\infty}$.
Lemma 1. Rules 1 and 2 can be applied exhaustively in linear time, increase the primal treewidth by at most one, and do not increase the incidence treewidth.

Proof. The first rule can be applied at most $|\varphi|$ times and takes, assuming any reasonable data structure to store $\varphi$, time $O(1)$. For the second rule, we just have to scan the clauses once and apply a constant number of operations per clause if necessary.

Since treewidth is hereditary, Rule 1 cannot increase it. To see that Rule 2 does increase the primal treewidth by at most one, take a bag of a tree decomposition of $G_{\varphi}$ that contains all variables of $c$. Add a new bag that contains all variables of $c$ and $\alpha$.

For the incidence case, there is a bag containing $c$, to which we can attach a bag $\{c, \alpha\}$. Note that if Rule 2 is applicable, there must be a bag containing at least two elements - hence, the incidence treewidth is not increased.

### 3.1 From MaxSAT to Max3SAT

The first step of our reductions is to ensure that every clause contains at most three literals. While this is a well-known operation, we must ensure that the treewidth is not increased. This turns out to be rather easy for the primal treewidth and quite tricky for the incidence treewidth.

Rule 3. Applicable if there is a $c=\left(\ell_{1} \vee \cdots \vee \ell_{q}\right)^{\infty}$ with $q>3$.
Replace $c$ with $\left(\ell_{1} \vee \ell_{2} \vee \alpha\right)^{\infty} \wedge\left(\neg \alpha \vee \ell_{3} \vee \cdots \vee \ell_{q}\right)^{\infty}$.
Lemma 2. Rule 3 can be applied exhaustively in linear time and increases the primal treewidth by at most one.

Proof. The rule can be applied at most $|c|-3$ times per clause and, thus, overall at most $O\left(\sum_{c \in \varphi}|c|\right)$ times - which is linear in the size of the formula.

For the claim on the treewidth, take a bag that contains all variables of $c$. Attach a new bag $b$ containing the variables of $c$ and $\alpha$ (this may increase the treewidth by one). Attach to this bag two new ones, one containing $\left\{\left|\ell_{1}\right|,\left|\ell_{2}\right|, \alpha\right\}$ and one containing $\left\{\left|\ell_{3}\right|, \ldots,\left|\ell_{q}\right|, \alpha\right\}$. In repeated applications of the rule, we never have to add a variable to $b$ : we can always create a new copy of the original bag or work with the two smaller bags - hence, the treewidth is increased by at most one in total.

Unfortunately, it is unclear in how far Rule 3 affects the incidence treewidth. The clause $c$ and its variables may be "smeared" across an optimal tree decomposition. Therefore, arbitrarily splitting the clause may increase the treewidth in an uncontrolled way. However, if we have access to a tree decomposition, we can apply the rule in a more controlled way to avoid this effect. Lampis et al. [27, Proposition A.1] showed how to apply the rule exhaustively such that the incidence treewidth grows from $k$ to $O(k)$ (using a complex program that processes the given tree decomposition). The following lemma improves this result in two ways: It is a direct encoding that does not require an involved program, and it determines the hidden factor to be two:

Lemma 3. There is a linear-time algorithm that, given a WCNF $\varphi$ and a width-k tree decomposition of $I_{\varphi}$, outputs a W3CNF $\psi$ with $\operatorname{itw}(\psi) \leq 2 k$ and $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi)=\operatorname{cost}(\psi)$.

Proof. We prove the claim in three steps: (i) we present the encoding, then (ii) we show its correctness, and finally (iii) we establish the claim about the treewidth. Importantly and in contrast to previous reduction rules, here we have access to a tree decomposition to guide our encoding.

For part (i), let $\varphi$ be the given WCNF and $(T, \chi)$ be a width- $k$ tree decomposition of the incidence graph $I_{\varphi}$. Our encoding consists of two parts: distributed variables that allow access to the variables of $\varphi$ in a controlled way along the tree decomposition; and an evaluation of clauses via simulated dynamic programming that ensures the semantics of $\varphi$. Let $\psi$ be the formula that we construct, and let

Distributed Variables: The first part of our encoding ensures that for all $x \in \operatorname{vars}(\varphi)$, all the copies $x^{t}$ in $\psi$ always have the same value. We will also say that these copies are synchronized. To that end, we introduce for every $t \in V(T)$, every $x \in \operatorname{vars}(\varphi) \cap \chi(t)$, and for every $t^{\prime} \in\left\{t^{\prime} \in\right.$ children $\left.(t) \mid x \in \chi\left(t^{\prime}\right)\right\}$ the following clauses:

$$
\left(x^{t} \leftrightarrow x^{t^{\prime}}\right)^{\infty} \equiv\left(\neg x^{t} \vee x^{t^{\prime}}\right)^{\infty} \wedge\left(x^{t} \vee \neg x^{t^{\prime}}\right)^{\infty}
$$

Simulated Dynamic Programming: To encode the semantics of $\varphi$ to $\psi$, we need to enforce that the variables corresponding to clauses are set to true at some point. This is achieved by adding for every $c \in \varphi$ the following clause:

$$
\left(c^{\operatorname{root}(T, c)}\right)^{w(c)}
$$

This (eventually soft) constraint says that the copy of $c$ closest to the root should be true. The weight thereby equals the weight of $c$. To conclude the encoding, whenever a $c^{t}$ is set to true, there must be a reason: either one of the literals of $c$ in $\chi(t)$ is true, or $c$ was already satisfied in a child of $t$. The following clause realizes this semantic:

This concludes the description of the encoding. To establish (ii), we first show $\operatorname{cost}(\psi) \leq \operatorname{cost}(\varphi)$ by proving that for every assignment $\alpha \models \varphi$ there is an assignment $\beta \models \psi$ with $\operatorname{cost}(\alpha)=\operatorname{cost}(\beta)$. Given $\alpha$, we first define a partial assignment that satisfies (1):

$$
\beta^{\prime}:=\bigcup_{\substack{t \in V(T) \\ x \in \operatorname{vars}(\varphi) \cap \chi(t)}} \underset{\substack{\text { t' } \in \operatorname{children}(t) \\ c \in \chi\left(t^{\prime}\right)}}{\vee}
$$

We extend $\beta^{\prime}$ to $\beta^{\prime \prime}$ by adding for every clause $c \in \varphi$ with $\alpha \models c$ the literal $c^{\operatorname{root}(T, c)}$ to $\beta^{\prime}$. By (2), we have $\operatorname{cost}(\alpha)=\operatorname{cost}\left(\beta^{\prime \prime}\right)$. We claim $\beta^{\prime \prime}$ can be extended to a satisfying assignment $\beta \models \psi$, for which we need to establish (3). Since $\alpha \models c$, there is a literal $\ell \in c \cap \alpha$. By the definition of $I_{\varphi}$ and the second property of tree decompositions, there is a bag $t \in V(T)$ with $\{|\ell|, c\} \subseteq \chi(t)$, i.e., $\left\{c^{t},|\ell|^{t}\right\} \subseteq \operatorname{vars}(\psi)$. According to the polarity of $\ell$, we add $|\ell|^{t}$ or $\neg|\ell|^{t}$ to $\beta^{\prime \prime}$. Then, adding $c^{t}$ to $\beta^{\prime \prime}$ is consistent with (3)

at $t$. We obtain $\beta$ by adding $c^{t^{\prime}}$ for every $t^{\prime} \in V(T)$ that lies on the unique path from $t$ to $\operatorname{root}(T, c)$, and $\neg c^{t^{\prime \prime}}$ for all other $t^{\prime \prime} \in V(T)$ with $c \in \chi\left(t^{\prime \prime}\right)$.

The other direction, i.e., $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi) \leq \operatorname{cost}(\psi)$, works similar: For every assignment $\beta \models \psi$ we construct an assignment $\alpha$ with $\alpha \models \varphi$ :

$$
\alpha:=\bigcup_{x \in \operatorname{vars}(\varphi)}\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
x^{t} & \text { if there is a } x^{t} \text { in } \beta \\
\neg x^{t} & \text { else }
\end{array}\right.
$$

Symmetric to the first direction, we have $\alpha \models c$ for all $c \in \varphi$ with $\beta \models c^{\operatorname{root}(T, c)}$ (but $\alpha$ may also satisfy clauses with $\beta \not \models c^{\operatorname{root}(T, c)}$ ). Hence, we have $\operatorname{cost}(\alpha) \leq \operatorname{cost}(\beta)$.

We continue with (iii) and prove that $\operatorname{itw}(\psi) \leq 2 k$ if the given tree decomposition of $I_{\varphi}$ has width $k$. To that end, we take the given tree decomposition $(T, \chi)$ of $I_{\varphi}$ and morph it into one of $I_{\psi}$. First, we rename in every bag $t \in V(T)$ nodes $x \in \operatorname{vars}(\varphi) \cap \chi(t)$ to $x^{t}$ and $c \in \varphi \cap \chi(t)$ to $c^{t}$. To every bag that contains a $c^{\operatorname{root}(T, c)}$, we attach a new bag containing $c^{\operatorname{root}(T, c)}$ and (2).

To continue, we add to $\chi(t)$ the constraint (3) for every $c \in \varphi \cap \chi(t)$, which may double the size of $\chi(t)$. This establishes the properties of an incidence tree decomposition for the first part of (3), e.g., the big-or over the literals. To establish the second part, e.g., the big-or over the children, we need to add the constraint to all children of $t$. This can be achieved without increasing the width by adding a chain of bags between $t$ and the child $t^{\prime}$. The first element of the chain contains $\chi(t) \backslash\left\{c^{t}\right\} \cup\left\{c^{t^{\prime}}\right\}$; then the next bag does not need to contain $c^{t^{\prime}}$, but may contain a $\tilde{c}^{t^{\prime}}$ for another clause $\tilde{c}$. This process is repeated until we reach $t^{\prime}$, to which nothing further is added. The bags along this chain have the size of $\chi(t)$, e.g., $2 k$. Finally, to establish (1), we proceed similarly: While connecting $t$ and $t^{\prime}$, we one-by-one add and forget vertices $x^{t^{\prime}}$. Then, on the chain from $t$ to $t^{\prime}$ there is a bag containing $x^{t}$ and $x^{t^{\prime}}$, to which we can attach two new bags containing these variables and one of the clauses of (1).

This almost concludes the proof: We have established a $\psi$ with $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi)=\operatorname{cost}(\psi)$, which has incidence treewidth at most $2 k$. However, $\psi$ is not a w3CNF due to (3) - and building such a formula is the whole point of the lemma! Fortunately, this can easily be fixed: It is well known that any tree decomposition can be transformed in linear time into one in which every node has either exactly one child introducing at most one new vertex, or two children with the same content [17, Chapter 7]. Transforming $(T, \chi)$ to this special form before applying the encoding from above ensures that (3) contains at most three literals.

# 3.2 From Max3SAT to Max2SAT 

To reduce from MAX3SAT to MAX2SAT, we first remove hard clauses by replacing them with soft clauses of high weight (referred to as top value).

Rule 4. Applicable if $\varphi$ contains hard clauses. Define

$$
h:=1+\sum_{c \in \varphi, w(c)<\infty} w(c) \quad \text { and } \quad \theta:=\sum_{c \in \varphi, w(c)=\infty} h
$$

and change the weight of every hard clause to $h$.
Let $\varphi^{\prime}$ be the formula obtained from $\varphi$ by applying Rule 4 . Then it is easy to see and well known that $\varphi$ is satisfiable iff $\operatorname{cost}\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)<\theta$ and that in that case $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi)=\operatorname{cost}\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)$. It is also clear that $\operatorname{tw}(\varphi)=\operatorname{tw}\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)$ and $\operatorname{itw}(\varphi)=\operatorname{itw}\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)$ as the rule only modifies weights. To move from MAX3sAT (without hard clauses) to MAX2SAT, we use:

Rule 5. Applicable if there is a $c=\left(\ell_{1} \vee \ell_{2} \vee \ell_{3}\right)^{h}$. Replace $c$ with $\left(\ell_{1} \vee \ell_{2}\right)^{h},\left(\ell_{1} \vee \ell_{3}\right)^{h},\left(\neg \ell_{2} \vee \neg \ell_{3}\right)^{h}$, $\left(\alpha \vee \neg \ell_{1}\right)^{h},\left(\neg \alpha \vee \ell_{2}\right)^{h}$, and $\left(\neg \alpha \vee \ell_{3}\right)^{h}$. Increase $\theta$ by $4 h$.

It was proven by Ansotegui et al. [5, Lemma 3] that Rule 5 is correct (observe that the set of clauses is unsatisfiable and that an assignment that satisfies $c$ satisfies exactly 5 of them, while an assignment violating $c$ satisfies only 4 of the new clauses).

Lemma 4. Rule 5 can be applied exhaustively in linear time and increase the primal treewidth by at most one and the incidence treewidth by at most a factor of three.

Proof. To apply the rule exhaustively, scanning over the formula once and printing a constant number of constant size clauses per encountered clause is sufficient. This is possible in time $O(|\varphi|)$.

For the statement about the primal treewidth, observe that there must be a bag $t$ containing $\left|\ell_{1}\right|,\left|\ell_{2}\right|$, and $\left|\ell_{3}\right|$. We attach a new bag $t^{\prime}$ with $\chi\left(t^{\prime}\right)=\left\{\left|\ell_{1}\right|,\left|\ell_{2}\right|,\left|\ell_{3}\right|, \alpha\right\}$ and obtain a tree decomposition of $\varphi^{\prime}$.

For the incidence treewidth, the situation is slightly more complex. In a tree decomposition of $I_{\varphi}$ there are three bags $t_{1}, t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ with $\left\{c,\left|\ell_{i}\right|\right\} \subseteq \chi\left(t_{i}\right)$ for $i \in\{1,2,3\}$, but there is no guarantee that any of the three variables appear together in a bag. By the properties of a tree decomposition, however, $c$ is contained in any bag that lies on a path between two of these bags. Hence, we can substitute $c$ in all bags by $\alpha,\left|\ell_{1}\right|,\left|\ell_{2}\right|$ without violating a property of the tree decomposition. Then $\left\{\alpha,\left|\ell_{1}\right|,\left|\ell_{2}\right|,\left|\ell_{3}\right|\right\} \subseteq \chi\left(t_{3}\right)$. This increases the treewidth by at most a factor of three and allows us to attach new bags to $t_{3}$ that connect the new clauses to the variables they contain.

Corollary 5. Rule 5 increases the primal treewidth to at most $\max (\mathrm{tw}, 3)$.
It is worth pointing out a difference to the previous section: While Rule 5 also increases the incidence treewidth by a multiplicative factor, it does not need a tree decomposition as input. If we are given a tree decomposition, we can extend Lemma 3 and directly output a w2CNF:

Lemma 5. There is a linear-time algorithm that, given a WCNF $\varphi$ and a width-k tree decomposition of $I_{\varphi}$, outputs a W2CNF $\psi$ with itw $(\psi) \leq 3 k$ and $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi)=\operatorname{cost}(\psi)$.

Proof. Use the encoding of Lemma 3 and utilize Rule 5 for constraint (3). The properties of a tree decomposition can be restored by simply adding $\alpha$ to all bags containing (3), which increases the treewidth to $3 k$.

# 3.3 From Max2SAT to Monotone Max2SAT 

In order to encode a MAX2SAT formula $\varphi$ into a QUBO, we first transform $\varphi$ such that every clause has the form $(
eg x)$ or $(
eg x \vee 
eg y)$, i.e., contains one or two negative literals. Such formulas are called monotone; hence, we reduce MAX2SAT to MON-MAX2SAT. Since every literal is negated in this problem, it represents a restriction of HORN-MAX2SAT.

Recall that after applying the previous rules, all clauses are soft, and a top value $h$ that simulates hard clauses is defined. A simple way to achieve the form is the use of double-railed logic by replacing every variable $x$ with $x^{+}$and $x^{-}$, every occurrence of $x$ with $
eg x^{-}$, and every occurrence of $
eg x$ with $
eg x^{+}$. We then encode $\left(x^{+} \leftrightarrow 
eg x^{-}ight)^{h}$ via $\left(
eg x^{+} \vee 
eg x^{-}ight)^{2 h},\left(
eg x^{+}ight)^{-h}$, and $\left(
eg x^{-}ight)^{-h}$. Observe that, in contrast to the definition of MAXSAT, we do allow negative weights here - otherwise MON-MAXSAT is a trivial problem. Also observe how the sum of the weights of the three clauses is $h$ if, and only if, $\left(
eg x^{+} \vee 
eg x^{-}ight)$evaluates to true. Unfortunately, this simple reduction increases even the primal treewidth by a factor of two. To preserve the treewidth as claimed, we perform the above sketched reduction locally.

Rule 6. Applicable if there is a clause $c=(x \vee \ell)^{w}$ with a positive literal $x$ (and an arbitrary literal $\ell$ ). Replace $c$ by $(
eg \alpha \vee \ell)^{w},(
eg \alpha \vee 
eg x)^{2 h},(
eg \alpha)^{-h}$, and $(
eg x)^{-h}$.

Lemma 6. Rule 6 can be applied exhaustively in linear time and increases both the primal and incidence treewidth by at most one.

Proof. The claim about the running time follows once more by the simple observation that every clause is replaced by a constant number of new clauses.

To see that the primal treewidth increases by at most one, take any tree decomposition of $G_{\varphi}$. There is a bag containing $x$ and $|\ell|$, to which we can attach a new bag containing $x,|\ell|$, and $\alpha$.

For the incidence treewidth, consider a tree decomposition of $I_{\varphi}$. We first replace $c$ in every bag with $\alpha$. Then there is a bag containing $\alpha$ and $|\ell|$ to which we attach a new bag containing $\alpha,|\ell|$, and $(
eg \alpha \vee \ell)$. Similarly, there are bags to which we can attach the other new clauses without increasing the width further.

Corollary 6. Rule 6 increases the primal treewidth to at most $\max (\mathrm{tw}, 2)$ and the incidence treewidth to at most $\max (\mathrm{itw}, 2)$.

# 3.4 From Monotone Max2SAT to QUBO 

Once we have a monotone WCNF, it is straightforward to transform it into a QUBO:
Rule 7. Applicable if there is a clause $c=(\neg x \vee \neg y)^{w}$. Replace $c$ by the term $-w x y$.
Observation 1. Rule 7 can be applied exhaustively in linear time and neither increases the primal nor the incidence treewidth.

The output of Rule 7 is a Hamiltonian $H$ whose ground states correspond to optimal models of the input formula. We collect the results that we have established in this section as:

Theorem 4. Applying Rules 1-7 exhaustively is possible in linear time and establishes a reduction from maxsat to qubo that increases the primal treewidth by at most one and the incidence treewidth by at most a factor of three.

### 3.5 From QUBO to MaxSAT

Encoding a qubo into maxsat is simpler. The following rule will transform a qubo into a max2sat instance without increasing the primal or incidence treewidth by more than one. Given a Hamiltonian

$$
H\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} x_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=i+1}^{n} w_{i j} x_{i} x_{j}
$$

we first translate the minimization problem of finding the ground state into a maximization problem by multiplying all weights with -1 . Then, we obtain a WCNF using:

Rule 8. For every $x_{i}$ in $H$ we introduce a variable $x_{i}$, for every $i \in\{1, \ldots, n\}$ and $j \in\{i+1, \ldots, n\}$ we introduce an auxiliary variable $\alpha_{i j}$. Then we replace:

- every term $w_{i} x_{i}$ with $w_{i}>0$ by a clause $\left(x_{i}\right)^{w_{i}}$;
- every term $w_{i} x_{i}$ with $w_{i}<0$ by a clause $\left(\neg x_{i}\right)^{-w_{i}}$;
- every term $w_{i j} x_{i} x_{j}$ with $w_{i j}>0$ by clauses $\left(\alpha_{i j}\right)^{w_{i j}},\left(\alpha_{i j} \rightarrow x_{i}\right)^{\infty}$, and $\left(\alpha_{i j} \rightarrow x_{j}\right)^{\infty}$;
- every term $w_{i j} x_{i} x_{j}$ with $w_{i j}<0$ by clauses $\left(\neg \alpha_{i j}\right)^{-w_{i j}},\left(\neg \alpha_{i j} \rightarrow x_{i}\right)^{\infty}$, and $\left(\neg \alpha_{i j} \rightarrow x_{j}\right)^{\infty}$.

Lemma 7. Rule 8 produces a WCNF $\varphi$ whose optimal models correspond to the ground states of $H$. The rule can be implemented in linear time and increases the primal and incidence treewidth by at most one.

Proof. The runtime follows as for previous rules, as we simply replace terms by a constant number of new clauses. As discussed before the rule, we can assume that the ground state of $H$ corresponds to a maximum point by multiplying all weights by -1 . That the translation to maxsat is correct for all terms with $w>0$ is evident. The logic is inverted for the remaining cases: It is "bad" to satisfy the terms of $H$, so it is "good" to satisfy the inverse.

Finally, it is easy to see that the primal treewidth increases by at most one, as for every term $w_{i j} x_{i} x_{j}$ there is a bag in the primal tree decomposition of $H$ that contains $x_{i}$ and $x_{j}$. By attaching a new bag containing $x_{i}, x_{j}$, and $\alpha_{i j}$, we obtain a primal tree decomposition of $\varphi$.

To see that the incidence treewidth is increased by at most one, take any tree decomposition of $I_{\varphi}$. All the cases of the rule are symmetric, so we only discuss the case in which the term $d=w_{i j} x_{i} x_{j}$ gets replaced by $\left(\alpha_{i j}\right)^{w_{i j}},\left(\alpha_{i j} \rightarrow x_{i}\right)^{\infty}$, and $\left(\alpha_{i j} \rightarrow x_{j}\right)^{\infty}$. We replace in every bag the term $d$ with $\alpha_{i j}$ and obtain two bags $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$ with $\left\{\alpha_{i j}, x_{i}\right\} \subseteq \chi\left(t_{1}\right)$ and $\left\{\alpha_{i j}, x_{j}\right\} \subseteq \chi\left(t_{2}\right)$. To $t_{1}$ we attach two new bags, one containing $\alpha_{i j}, x_{i}$, and $\left(\alpha_{i j} \rightarrow x_{i}\right)^{\infty}$; and one that contains $\alpha_{i j}$ and $\left(\alpha_{i j}\right)^{w_{i j}}$. Similarly, we attach a new bag to $t_{2}$ containing $\alpha_{i j}, x_{j}$, and $\left(\alpha_{i j} \rightarrow x_{j}\right)^{\infty}$.

Corollary 7. Rule 8 increases the primal treewidth to at most max(tw, 2) and the incidence treewidth to at most $\max (\mathrm{itw}, 2)$.

## 4 Intermezzo: Upper Bounds for Max2SAT

Our reduction rules allow us to establish lower bounds for fragments of MAXSAT under SETH and ETH. The following section considers upper bounds for fragments of MAXSAT. Before we get there, let us first review the complexity of maxsat with respect to the parameter treewidth.

It is straightforward (and folklore) to develop algorithms to solve MAXSAT in time $O\left(2^{\operatorname{tw}(\varphi)} \operatorname{tw}(\varphi)^{2}|\varphi|\right)$ and $O\left(2^{2 \operatorname{itw}(\varphi)} \operatorname{itw}(\varphi)^{2}|\varphi|\right)$. It is known that the polynomial dependency on the treewidth can be removed by implementing the underlying dynamic programs more carefully $[9,11,12]$ :

Fact 1. MAXSAT can be solved in time $O\left(2^{\operatorname{tw}(\varphi)}|\varphi|\right)$ and $O\left(2^{2 \operatorname{itw}(\varphi)}|\varphi|\right)$.
Note the gap between the primal and incidence treewidth, i.e., the second running time contains a factor of two in the exponent. This gap is not present in binary formulas:

Lemma 8. MAX2SAT can be solved in time $O\left(2^{\operatorname{itw}(\varphi)}|\varphi|\right)$.
Proof. In the incidence graph of a w2CNF, all vertices corresponding to clauses have a maximum degree of 2. By the almost simplicial rule, contracting such a vertex to one of its neighbors cannot increase the treewidth past 2 [10]. However, contracting all vertices corresponding to a clause to one of their neighbors yields exactly the primal graph, and, hence, we have $\operatorname{tw}(\varphi) \leq \operatorname{itw}(\varphi)$. The claim follows by Fact 1.

Corollary 8. QUBO can be solved in time $O\left(2^{\operatorname{itw}(H)}|H|\right)$.
Lemma 8 and the corollary establish Theorem 2. The next section establishes similar results for fragments of MAXSAT with arbitrary large clauses.

# 5 Cost-optimal Reasoning via Model Counting 

In this section, we present stronger upper bounds for fragments of MAXSAT by reducing these problems to the model counting problem \#SAT, i.e., to the task of counting the number of satisfying assignments of a (unweighted) CNF. We establish Theorem 3 in the form of three lemmas, one per item in the statement. The variants are defined below.

- unARY-MAXsAT: Weights are given in unary and are, therefore, polynomially bounded by the input size.
- MULT-MAXSAT: Weights are powers of 2, and we optimize for the product of weights instead of the sum.
- LEX-MAXSAT: The goal is to compute the lexicographically largest model, in which we first optimize for the largest number of variables with the largest weight, then for those with the second-largest weight, and so on.
To encode these problems into \#SAT, it will be convenient to assume that the weights are defined on variables rather than clauses, i.e., $w: \operatorname{vars}(\varphi) \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$. In this setting, the costs of an assignment are $\operatorname{cost}(\beta)=\sum_{x \notin \beta} w(x)$, and we let $w(\beta)=\sum_{x \in \beta} w(x)$. By Rule 2 , this is not a restriction and does not increase the incidence treewidth.

Unary-Weighted MaxSAT. For unary weights, the reduction works in two steps. First, we present a structure-aware elimination of unary weights. Then, we use the lemma below to translate MAXSAT to \#SAT with only a constant increase of the incidence treewidth.

Lemma 9. There is a linear-time reduction from MAXSAT with weights given in unary to MAXSAT with weights at most one such that the incidence treewidth is increased by at most one.

Proof. Let $\varphi$ be a WCNF whose weight function $w$ is given in unary. For every variable $x \in \operatorname{vars}(\varphi)$ with $w(x)>1$ we use $w(x)$ fresh weighted variables $w_{i}$ with weight 1 . We construct $w(x)$ clauses of the form $c_{i}=\left(x \vee \neg w_{i}\right)$ for every $i \in\{1, \ldots, w(x)\}$. This ensures that we can only get the weight of $x$ (via weighted variables $w_{i}$ ) in case $x$ is set to true. Observe that this increases the incidence treewidth by at most 1 , as the fresh variables $w_{i}$ do not need to occur in a common decomposition bag. Indeed, one can manipulate any tree decomposition of $I_{\varphi}$ by finding a bag containing $x$, attaching new bags containing $\left\{x, c_{i}\right\}$, to which another child with $\left\{c_{i}, w_{i}\right\}$ is added.

Lemma 10. There is a linear-time reduction from MAXSAT with weights at most one to \#SAT such that the incidence treewidth is increased by at most one.

Proof. Observe that there can be at most $2^{|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|}$ (satisfying) assignments of $\varphi$. In order to support this largest number, we require a base weight larger than $2^{|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|}$. We use the base weight $2^{|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1}$ and

eliminate 1 -weights by extending $\varphi$ to a new formula $\varphi^{\prime}$. Precisely, for every variable $x$ with $w(x)=1$, we use $|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1$ auxiliary variables of the form $w_{i}^{x}$ and add clauses $c_{i}^{x}=\left(x \vee w_{i}^{x}\right)$ for $i \in\{1, \ldots,|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|\}$.

Observe that the construction of $\varphi^{\prime}$ ensures that every satisfying assignment $\beta$ of $\varphi^{\prime}$ is duplicated $\left(2^{|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1}\right)^{w(\beta)}=2^{w(\beta) \cdot(|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1)}$ times. Indeed, the number $\#\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)$ of satisfying assignments of $\varphi^{\prime}$ is of the form $\sum_{\beta \mid=\varphi} 2^{w(\beta) \cdot(|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1)}$, which makes it convenient to compute the maximal weight. One can check whether the maximal solution has weight at least $w$ if $\frac{\#\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)}{2^{w(|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1)}}>0$. Note that this division works in polynomial time, using binary-encoded digits and we only need a polynomial number of these queries. To see that the incidence treewidth is increased by at most one, take for every variable $x$ with $w(x)=1$ a bag containing $x$, attach for every $i \in\{1, \ldots,|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|\}$ a new bag containing $\left\{x, c_{i}^{x}\right\}$, and attach to this bag $\left\{c_{i}^{x}, w_{i}^{x}\right\}$.

Observe that both lemmas do not increase the incidence treewidth if the formula is not trivial, i.e., if it contains at least one clause. In particular, applying both lemmas increases the incidence treewidth by at most one. With both lemmas at hand, we obtain the following result.

Lemma 11 (First Part of Theorem 3). unARY-MAXSAT can be solved in time $O\left(2^{\text {itw }(\varphi)}\right) \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)$.
Proof. Apply Lemmas 9 and 10, and use the algorithm by Slivovsky and Szeider [44] to compute $\#\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)$ in time $O\left(2^{\text {itw }\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)}\right) \operatorname{poly}\left(\left|\varphi^{\prime}\right|\right)$.

Multiplicative MaxSAT. With multiplicative weights, we follow a similar construction. However, we need to utilize binary search to end up with a polynomial-time algorithm. We obtain the following new result.

Lemma 12 (Second Part of Theorem 3). MULT-MAXSAT can be solved in time $O\left(2^{\text {itw }(\varphi)}\right) \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)$.
Proof. We perform a reduction similarly to Lemma 10 but require a binary search to determine the largest weight. Again, we construct a formula $\varphi^{\prime}$ by extending $\varphi$ using the base weight $2^{|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1}$. For every $x \in \operatorname{vars}(\varphi)$ with weight $2^{w(x)}$, we use $w(x) \cdot(|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1)$ auxiliary variables of the form $w_{i}^{x}$ and clauses $c_{i}^{x}=\left(x \vee w_{i}^{x}\right)$ for every $i \in\{1, \ldots, w(x) \cdot(|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1)\}$. The construction ensures that satisfying assignments $\beta$ are duplicated $\left(2^{|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1}\right)^{w(\beta)}=2^{w(\beta) \cdot(|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1)}$ times. Indeed, the number $\#\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)$ of satisfying assignments of $\varphi^{\prime}$ is of the form $\sum_{\beta \mid=\varphi} 2^{w(\beta) \cdot(|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1)}$, which makes it convenient to use binary search to compute the maximal weight. We compute $\#\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)$ as in Lemma 11 and, during the binary search, check whether the maximal solution has weight at least $2^{w}$, namely if $\frac{\#\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)}{2^{w(|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1)}}>0$. Note that $w$ is polynomial in the input size, i.e., the binary search only needs a polynomial number of divisions. To conclude the proof, observe that the claim for the incidence treewidth is analog to Lemma 11.

Lexicographic MaxSAT. This variant can be directly instantiated as MULT-MAXSAT.
Lemma 13 (Third Part of Theorem 3). LEX-MAXSAT can be solved in time $O\left(2^{\text {itw }(\varphi)}\right) \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)$.
Proof. We translate LEX-MAXSAT to MULT-MAXSAT as follows: For the smallest weight, we use $2^{0}$ as multiplicative weight, for the second-smallest $2^{|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1}$, and so on, which leaves the largest (say, $n$-th smallest) weight with $2^{n(|\operatorname{vars}(\varphi)|+1)}$. Note that weights might reoccur if they did in the original instance. We can determine the lexicographically largest weight via binary search, as in Lemma 12.

# 6 Conclusion and Future Research 

The recent rise of Ising machines created a demand for efficient encodings into MAX2SAT and QUBO. Reductions from MAXSAT to MAX2SAT were previously considered to be of only theoretical interest [5] and, surprisingly, have not been studied so far with structural parameters like treewidth in mind. It is surprising in the sense that solving a QUBO using an IPU requires an embedding from the problem into the hardware, which may only be possible if the Hamiltonian has small treewidth [47]. Hence, if any part of the chain from MAXSAT to MAX2SAT to QUBO increases the treewidth non-negligible, using an IPU may not be feasible at all.

We showed that maxsat is equivalent to qubo under treewidth-preserving reductions. Our reductions are tight for primal treewidth because they introduce, at most, a constant additive factor to the treewidth. As an immediate consequence, we obtain an algorithm to solve qubos in time $2^{\operatorname{tw}(H)} \operatorname{poly}(|H|)$. These

Table 1: An overview of the lower (under SETH) and upper bounds established in this article for various versions of MAXSAT. A line is highlighted if the bounds match. Note that all bounds are ETH-tight.

![table_0](table_0)

reductions also imply new lower bounds under SETH for MAX2SAT and QUBO, which are tight for primal treewidth. Table 1 summarizes all the lower and upper bounds we have achieved.

For the incidence treewidth, our reductions only introduce a multiplicative factor of three. This implies a $2^{2 \text { itw }(\varphi)} \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)$ algorithm for MAXSAT - while reductions with an additive increase of the incidence treewidth would imply a SETH-optimal algorithm of running time $2^{\text {itw }(\varphi)} \operatorname{poly}(|\varphi|)$. The first immediate question is whether the result for incidence treewidth can be improved to increase the incidence treewidth by only an additive factor:

Open Problem 1. Is there a polynomial-time algorithm that, given a formula $\varphi$ and a width-k tree decomposition of $I_{\varphi}$, outputs a W2CNF $\psi$ and a width- $(k+O(1))$ tree decomposition of $I_{\psi}$ such that $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi)=\operatorname{cost}(\psi) ?$

The second downside of the reduction rules for incidence treewidth is that they require a tree decomposition. Unfortunately, this is already the case for the reduction to MAX3SAT.

Open Problem 2. Is there a polynomial-time algorithm that maps WCNFs $\varphi$ to W3CNFs $\psi$ such that itw $(\psi) \leq O(\operatorname{itw}(\varphi))$ and $\operatorname{cost}(\varphi)=\operatorname{cost}(\psi) ?$

From a practical perspective, the next natural step in this line of research is an experimental evaluation of the proposed approach using different IPU architectures and to compare these hardware accelerators to state-of-the-art MAXSAT solvers. From the automated reasoning perspective, it would be interesting to study MAxSat solvers that actively utilize binary clauses. There may be benchmarks on which such tools have an advantage in conjunction with the proposed reductions.

abstract:
Hardware accelerators like quantum annealers or neuromorphic chips are
capable of finding the ground state of a Hamiltonian. A promising route in
utilizing these devices is via methods from automated reasoning: The problem at
hand is first encoded into MaxSAT; then MaxSAT is reduced to Max2SAT; and
finally, Max2SAT is translated into a Hamiltonian. It was observed that
different encodings can dramatically affect the efficiency of the hardware
accelerators. Yet, previous studies were only concerned with the size of the
encodings rather than with syntactic or structural properties.
  We establish structure-aware reductions between MaxSAT, Max2SAT, and the
quadratic unconstrained binary optimization problem (QUBO) that underlies such
hardware accelerators. All these problems turn out to be equivalent under
linear-time, treewidth-preserving reductions. As a consequence, we obtain tight
lower bounds under ETH and SETH for Max2SAT and QUBO, as well as a new
time-optimal fixed-parameter algorithm for QUBO. While our results are tight up
to a constant additive factor for the primal treewidth, we require a constant
multiplicative factor for the incidence treewidth. To close the emerging gap,
we supplement our results with novel time-optimal algorithms for fragments of
MaxSAT based on model counting.
